author: yustian prayitno

text: I've beat this game so many times... I can never get over how truly amazing this game is. The graphics are amazing, the story line is great. The fantasy-based artwork is beautiful, and all the music is from a real symphony, not made with computers. I can't believe that, even after all these years, this game never ceases to amaze me. Konami did a wonderful job when making this one, and I hope to see one just as good as this in the future. The other games are all right, but none can compare. :'D

text:
@AllAboutEights gotta disagree there.
it had TWO peaks
Castlevania:  8/10
Castlevania 2 Simon's Quest:  6/10
Castlevania 3: 8/10
Super Castlevania 4: 10/10
Castlevania Dracula X: 8/10
Castlevania Bloodlines: 8/10
Castlevania 64: 5/10
Castlevania Symphony of the Night: 10/10....
knock em into groups of four.
every 4th game is AMAZING...
And one among the group is shit
and one of the other three is shit

text: The music on this game was absolutely incredible, the game itself was as well, and no other Castlevania so far has come close to this I have to say. I remember a week before this game came out, it was talked about in my high school news paper, which was awesome. This music always reminded me of flying around at night, which is something I always often thought about dunno why. My mom thought this one was so beautiful, it now reminds me of how happy she'd get when it played.

text: I'm going to have to disagree with you on the N64 two.  I was really disappointed with the jump to 3D, I still don't think they've got it yet.  I mean when I played Mario 64, and it was awesome, then I played Castlevania 64 and it was (insert antonym for awesome); I mean that was the first Castlevania that I never played through and I don't understand how Konami could turn it out like that.  Sorry, I didn't really intend to demean your post, just my opinion.

author: sfried

text:
"You're just a nostalgic twit?" Maybe you're just less skilled.

To shenloken: I appreciate your opinion and stand corrected, but I still do believe there is life left with the traditional linear Castlevania format. Newer Castleroids seem to focus too much on simply collecting better equipment and grinding to defeat bosses, although that seems to be changing with Order of Ecclesia. I do think they could use the idea of branching paths and bite-size levels more.
author: sfried

author: countrybluegrass

text:
You should've started playing it on the NES. Only then would you have a firm appreciation of the series roots.

One common mistake people of your era assume is that Castlevania is all about sprawling environments. Back then it was more linear, with hidden passages and branching paths. It was also alot harder, too.
